title: No, these cars did not melt due to hot weather | Fact Check
htmlTitle: No, these cars did not melt due to hot weather | Fact Check
snippet: Jun 27, 2019 ... A photo of two partially melted cars has been shared hundreds of ... “Hot Temprature in Arizona due to fire in forest is melting cars”.
htmlSnippet: Jun 27, 2019 ... A photo of two partially melted cars has been shared hundreds of ... “Hot Temprature in Arizona due to fire in forest is melting cars”.

metatags.twitter:title: Os veículos e o semáforo nestas imagens não derreteram devido a
metatags.og:title: No, these cars did not melt due to hot weather
metatags.og:description: A photo of two partially melted cars has been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook posts that claim hot weather in Saudi Arabia caused the vehicles to melt. Other misleading posts combine the same photo with claims it shows the result of hot weather in other locations, or a forest fire. All the claims are false; the cars were melted by heat from a construction site fire in the US city of Tucson in June 2018.
metatags.twitter:creator: @afpfactuel

metatags.og:description:
The temperature in Pheonix has almost reached a record-breaking 122 °F (50 °C) recorded on June 26, 1990, and it's becoming harder and harder to escape the insane heat. The flights are being cancelled, and things are literally melting.
Today it's up to 116 °F (47 °C), and 168 °F (76°C) on the concrete.
metatags.og:title: Temperatures In Arizona Are So High Right Now That People Are Posting Pics Of Things Melting
metatags.article:author: https://www.facebook.com/boredpanda/

comment.text: Fake rock plastic wall...in a dessert climate zone. Well...challenge accepted, challenge lost...
Let's all agree that Arizona is hot as hell, just eat the cookie
How do you take the picture
The 'a' looks like a smiling face and 'o' looks like a mouth
It's nice to see responsible pet owners!!
This sure makes it difficult for the mailman to deliver the mail.
That's genius, but also slightly creepy.
Looks like Hell - literally I mean. :/
That's not melting, that's a slow painful death by wilting.
They have cancelled or postponed flights in Palm Springs, CA also, same reason. It's not all that uncommon in Palm Springs.
It may have just fallen it, or it may have been drying out and needed to re-hydrate its book lungs.
Kudos to you for appreciating the sound of vinyl! Hope you can get that replaced.
And here I am in Zurich, Switzerland, diying with 32 degrees (i have every day migraine headache because of the heat) and you all have to live in the hell.
I live in Dubai where temperatures easily reach 50 degrees Celsius. I've never seen anything melt like that
They called it Phoenix for a good reason.

title: You Should Never Keep These 10 Things in Your Car on a Hot Day
htmlTitle: You Should Never Keep These 10 Things in Your Car on a Hot Day
snippet: Aug 8, 2018 ... So even if your car isn't stolen this summer, everything inside could end up baking in the heat and getting damaged if you're not careful. To ...

metatags.sailthru.tags: Features, BI-freelancer, BITranspo, Car, Summer, Heat, Temperature, Weather, Cars, Steven John
metatags.title: 10 things not to keep in your car in the summer
metatags.og:description: A car parked in the sun on an 72-degree day can reach an internal 119 degrees in less than an hour. There are things that you should never leave in a car in the summer, like pets and tech devices, due to the risk of damage from heat. Here are 10 things you should never leave in the car on a hot day.

question.text: Facebook just posted to my timeline this picture claiming that cars in Arizona are melting in the heat. Is it true?

answer.text: The weather is not melting cars. But there was a big fire in Tucson and the heat from the fire melted plastic parts on a bunch of cars in the parking lot. The pictures in this article fairly...
